title: Generic argument handling with Associated type bounds
body:
<!--
Thank you for filing a bug report! 🐛 Please provide a short summary of the bug,
along with any information you feel relevant to replicating the bug.
-->

I tried this code:

```rust
trait Foo {
    type Bar;
}

trait Copy {}

fn c<F: Foo<Bar: Foo>>()
where
    F::Bar: Copy,
{
}
```

I expected to see this happen: compile

Instead, this happened: 

```
test.rs:8:13: error: generic item takes at most 1 type arguments but 1 were supplied
    2 | trait Foo {
      | ~            
......
    8 | fn c<F: Foo<Bar: Foo>>()
      |             ^
test.rs:10:8: error: failed to resolve path segment using an impl Probe
   10 |     F::Bar: Copy,
      |        ^
rust1: error: Failed to lookup type reference for node: F::Bar

```

The PR #1716 added support to parse this associated type bounds but it is currently being treated as a general type argument which is not correct and we need a new way to represent this in the AST and HIR

### Meta

- What version of Rust GCC were you using, git sha if possible.
0bab8d932c985ba83be0ebe258da30b51c117be4
